headline.main: As National Geographic explores obesity, critics question the food ads in its children's magazine

docs.abstract: Center for Science in Public Interest complains to National Geographic Society that its National Geographic Kids magazine contributes to obesity problem by running ads for unhealthy foods; complaint comes as National Geographic magazine tackles obesity in cover story; National Geographic Kids publisher Rainer Jenss pledges to carefully consider complaint; notes parents are real gatekeepers between advertising industry and children; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: JUST as National Geographic magazine is tackling obesity in a cover story called ''The Heavy Cost of Fat,'' its younger sibling, National Geographic Kids, is being accused of contributing to the obesity problem by running ads for unhealthy food. The Center for Science in the Public Interest has sent a letter to the National Geographic Society, publisher of the magazines, complaining about the ads for products like Hostess cupcakes and Kellogg's Smorz cereal in the publications.
docs.snippet: JUST as National Geographic magazine is tackling obesity in a cover story called ''The Heavy Cost of Fat,'' its younger sibling, National Geographic Kids, is being accused of contributing to the obesity problem by running ads for unhealthy food.   ...

headline.main: From Green and Leafy to a Sharper Brain

docs.abstract: Dr Jae Hee Kang, Brigham and Women's Hospital instructor, leads study that suggests eating cruciferous and green leafy vegetables can help maintain mental acuity in older women; study, presented at International Conference on Alzheimer's Disease and Related Disorders, finds less mental decline in women who ate about eight servings rather than three servings of green leafy vegetable per week and in women who ate about five servings instead to two of cruciferous vegetables per week; although findings were extracted from long-running nurse's health study data, experts indicate similar benefits are likely for men (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Now there is another reason to eat your vegetables. A new study suggests that certain vegetables may help older women keep their brains sharper. The researchers found that over time women in their 60's who ate more cruciferous and green leafy vegetables than other women did went on to show less overall decline on tests that measured memory, verbal ability and attention.
docs.snippet: Now there is another reason to eat your vegetables. A new study suggests that certain vegetables may help older women keep their brains sharper.    The researchers found that over time women in their 60's who ate more cruciferous and green leafy...

headline.main: Bayer in Deal For Roche's Consumer Unit

docs.abstract: German chemical and drug giant Bayer will buy Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche's over-the-counter drug business in deal worth about 2.38 billion euros ($2.95 billion); deal would enlarge Bayer's New Jersey-based consumer health care unit; graph of largest nonprescription drug makers; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Bayer, the German chemical and drug giant that makes aspirin and Alka-Seltzer, said Monday that it would buy the over-the-counter drug business of the Swiss pharmaceuticals company Roche in a transaction worth about $2.95 billion that would create a world leader in nonprescription medicines. If the 2.38 billion euro deal is approved by antitrust officials in Europe and the United States, the enlarged Bayer consumer health care unit, which would continue to be based in Morristown, N.J., would be led by Gary S. Balkema, the president of Bayer Healthcare. The combined operations would have 6,700 employees in 120 countries.
docs.snippet: Bayer, the German chemical and drug giant that makes aspirin and Alka-Seltzer, said Monday that it would buy the over-the-counter drug business of the Swiss pharmaceuticals company Roche in a transaction worth about $2.95 billion that would create a...

headline.main: Weight-Loss Field Awaits Change in Medicare Policy

byline.original: By GINA KOLATA and DENISE GRADY

docs.abstract: Health and Human Services Sec Tommy G Thompson announces that Medicare will recognize obesity as disease; Medicare may cover weight-loss treatments that are proven to be effective, but will also fund studies to determine effectiveness and set standards for success; estimated 18 percent of Medicare population meets definition of obese; decision is significant becaue many insurers take their cues from Medicare policies (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The new policy announced by the federal government last week that enables Medicare to consider paying for obesity treatments may transform the weight-loss field by providing, for the first time, reliable data on methods for losing weight. Health and Human Services Secretary Tommy G. Thompson announced Thursday that Medicare was abandoning a long-held policy that said obesity was not a disease, opening the way for the government to pay for a whole range of possible treatments, from surgery and diets to psychotherapy. But the government also said that to be eligible for coverage, treatments must be proved effective. And to determine whether an obesity treatment works, Medicare says it could end up paying for large studies of the treatment's effectiveness.
docs.snippet: The new policy announced by the federal government last week that enables Medicare to consider paying for obesity treatments may transform the weight-loss field by providing, for the first time, reliable data on methods for losing weight.     Health...

headline.main: A Deletion Opens Medicare To Coverage for Obesity

byline.original: By MARK GLASSMAN; Robert Pear contributed reporting for this article

docs.abstract: Small change in language of government manual opens door for obesity treatments to be covered by Medicare; American Obesity Assn says 18 percent of Medicare population is obese (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: A small change in the language of a government manual has opened the door for obesity treatments to be covered under Medicare, the Bush administration said on Thursday. A new policy handed down by the Department of Health and Human Services removes the phrase ''obesity itself cannot be considered an illness'' from the Medicare Coverage Issues Manual, allowing scientists, clinicians and companies to submit proposals recommending that certain treatments be covered. The change was first reported on Thursday in The Wall Street Journal.
docs.snippet: A small change in the language of a government manual has opened the door for obesity treatments to be covered under Medicare, the Bush administration said on Thursday.    A new policy handed down by the Department of Health and Human Services...
